contextId.information: "Judah" refers to the southern kingdom of Israel. "Jerusalem" was its most important city. AT: "those living in Judah and Jerusalem" or "the people of Judah and Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Judah and Jerusalem

contextId.information: The words "new moons" are a metonym for the celebrations of the new moon. They are also a synecdoche for all regular celebrations. AT: "your celebrations of the new moon and your other regular feasts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: your new moons and your appointed feasts

contextId.information: The word "sword" refers to Judah's enemies. Also, the word "devour" compares Judah's enemies coming to kill them to a wild animal that attacks and eats other animals. AT: "your enemies will kill you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the sword will devour you

contextId.information: This exclamation shows Isaiah's anger and sadness about the people of Jerusalem. AT: "See how the people of Jerusalem, who had been faithful to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: How the faithful city

contextId.information: "Judah" and "Jerusalem" are metonyms for the people who live there. AT: "those living in Judah and Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Judah and Jerusalem

contextId.information: "no nation will lift up its sword against another nation." The sword is a metonym for war. AT: "one nation will not fight wars against another nation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: nation will not lift up sword against nation

contextId.information: "You descendants of Jacob" (UDB). The word "house" is a metonym for the people who live in the house, the family. Here "Jacob" represents the nation of Judah, but it would be best to use "Jacob" here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: House of Jacob

contextId.information: Clasping hands together is the symbol of friendship and peace. AT: "they make peace and work together with people who are not from Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: and they shake hands with sons of foreigners

contextId.information: Falling represents being killed, and the sword represents battle. AT: "Your men will be killed in battle, and your strong men will be killed in war" or "Enemies will kill your soldiers in battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Your men will fall by the sword, and your strong men will fall in war

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks of the city gates weeping as if they were people as a metonym for the people who will weep at the public places near the gates. AT: "The people of Jerusalem will sit at the city gates and cry and mourn" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Jerusalem's gates will lament and mourn

contextId.information: "Blood stains" here represents violence and murder. AT: "and will have taken away those in Jerusalem who harm innocent people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: and will have cleansed the blood stains from Jerusalem's midst

contextId.information: The size of the vineyard is represented by the number of pairs of oxen that could plow it in one day. Each pair of oxen would be connected by a yoke. AT: "a vineyard that is large enough for ten pairs of oxen to plow it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: a ten-yoke vineyard

contextId.information: Looking down is often a sign of being ashamed. AT: "the eyes of proud people will look down in shame" or "people who were proud are now ashamed." See how you translated similar words in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:02:09|2:11]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the eyes of the lofty will be cast down

contextId.information: Here "hand" represents God's power and control. Isaiah speaks as if Yahweh were a person about to hit another person with his fist. This is a metaphor for Yahweh punishing Israel. AT: "he will still be ready to punish them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: his hand is still stretched out

contextId.information: Here "lips" represent what a person speaks. And, people saying things that are unacceptable to God is spoken of as if their lips were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: of unclean lips

contextId.information: Here "voice" represents the Lord himself. AT: "the Lord say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the voice of the Lord say

contextId.information: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the house of David heard the report" or "someone reported to the house of David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: It was reported to the house of David

contextId.information: Here "Aram" and "Ephraim" refer to their kings. Ephraim is used here to refer to the whole northern kingdom of Israel. AT: "that Rezin, the king of Aram was helping Pekah, the king of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: that Aram was allied with Ephraim

contextId.information: The words "Aram" and "Ephraim" refer to the kings of these lands. Also, "Ephraim" refers to the northern kingdom of Israel. AT: "Rezin the king of Aram and Pekah the son of Remaliah, king of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Aram, Ephraim, and the son of Remaliah

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family living in the house. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:07:01|7:2]]. AT: "King Ahaz, you and your counselors" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: house of David

contextId.information: "the people of Ephraim separated from the people of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Ephraim seceded from Judah

contextId.information: the Euphrates River in Assyria. This is a metonym for the Assyrian soldiers, who will come from their homes by the Euphrates River ([[:en:bible:notes:isa:08:05|8:7]]). (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The River

contextId.information: Yahweh's "face" is a metonym for his blessing or favor. AT: "who has taken away his blessing from the house of Jacob" or "who no longer looks with favor on the house of Jacob" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: who hides his face from the house of Jacob

contextId.information: Here "it" refers to Galilee which represents the people who live there. AT: "but in the future, the Lord will honor the people of Galilee of the nations, which is on the road between the Mediterranean Sea and the Jordan River" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: but in the later time he will make it glorious, the way to the sea, beyond the Jordan, Galilee of the nations

contextId.information: The hand is a metonym for either the king's power or his army. AT: "In my power I have seized" or "My army has seized" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: My hand has seized

contextId.information: This refers to when God caused the water of the Red Sea to split so the people of Israel could escape from the Egyptian army and so that the Egyptian army would drown in it. AT: "He will help you escape from the army of Assyria as he helped your ancestors escape the army of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He will raise his rod over the sea and lift it up as he did in Egypt

contextId.information: Here the word "spirit" refers to an ability or quality that the Spirit of Yahweh would give him. AT: "and he will cause him to have wisdom and understanding, instruction and might, knowledge and the fear of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the spirit of wisdom ... the spirit of instruction ... the spirit of knowledge ... the fear of Yahweh

contextId.information: The name of the city stands for the people of Babylon. AT: "about the people of Babylon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: about Babylon

contextId.information: This refers to "the people of the world." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the world

contextId.information: "Before their eyes" means "in their presence" or "while they watch." It can be stated clearly that the parents are unable to help their infants.  AT: "while their parents helplessly watch" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: before their eyes

contextId.information: Here "Jacob" refers to the descendants of Jacob. AT: "Yahweh will have mercy on the descendants of Jacob" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will have compassion on Jacob

contextId.information: This refers to the Israelites, the descendants of Israel. AT: "the descendants of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Israel

contextId.information: The "proud fury" refers to the the king of Babylon being proud and treating other nations cruelly. AT: "his cruelty has ended" or "he can no longer oppress people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the proud fury ended

contextId.information: The staff of the wicked probably refers to a stick that wicked people would hit other people with. Breaking that stick represents destroying their power to treat people cruelly. AT: "Yahweh has destroyed the power of the wicked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh has broken the staff of the wicked

contextId.information: This refers to everyone on earth. AT: "everyone on earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The whole earth

contextId.information: This means that God will do something against them. The word "them" refers to the people of Babylon. AT: "I will attack them" or "I will send people to attack them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will rise up against them

contextId.information: Here "gate" and "city" represent the people at the city gates and in the cities. "Howl, you people at the city gates; cry, you people in the cities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Howl, gate; cry, city

contextId.information: These city names represent the people of these cities. "The people of Heshbon and Elealeh call out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Heshbon and Elealeh call out

contextId.information: The heart represents the emotions. God speaks of his great sadness as if his heart cried out. AT: "I am extremely sad about what is happening to Moab" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] or [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: My heart cries out for Moab

contextId.information: Here "throne" refers to the power to rule as king. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh will be faithful to the covenant and he will appoint a king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: A throne will be established in covenant faithfulness

contextId.information: "Moab" represents the people of Moab. "So all the people of Moab will cry out loud over what has happened to their cities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: So Moab wails for Moab—they all wail

contextId.information: The "shouts of joy" represent people shouting for joy about the harvest of their fruit trees. AT: "Because of what I will do, you will no longer shout for joy when you harvest your fields of summer fruit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: For on your fields of summer fruits and harvest I have ended the shouts of joy

contextId.information: The phrase "my heart" represents Yahweh and his sad feelings. He compares his sigh to the sound of a sad song played on a harp. AT: "So I sigh like a sad song on a harp" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: So my heart sighs like a harp for Moab

contextId.information: The word "Moab" refers to the people of Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: concerning Moab

contextId.information: Looking to the altars represents worshiping idols with the hope that the idols will help them.  AT: "They will not worship idols at their altars" or "The people of Israel will not go to their altars and ask their idols to help them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: They will not look to the altars

contextId.information: The second phrase identifies the things that the people made. Speaking of the fingers here emphasizes that the people made them, so these things are not real gods. AT: "the Asherah poles or the sun images, which they themselves made" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: what their fingers have made ... the Asherah poles or the sun images

contextId.information: Possible meanings of "the rustling of wings" are 1) wings represent boats that have sails. AT: "Woe to those who live in the land beyond the rivers of Ethiopia, whose many ships look like insects on the water" or 2) the rustling of wings refers to the noise of insects that have wings, perhaps locusts. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Woe to the land of the rustling of wings, which is along the rivers of Ethiopia

contextId.information: Trampling down represents conquering other nations. AT: "a nation that is strong and conquers other nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: a nation strong and trampling down

contextId.information: The word "name" refers to Yahweh. AT: "to Mount Zion, where Yahweh of hosts dwells" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to the place of the name of Yahweh of hosts, to Mount Zion

contextId.information: Here "hand" refers to power or control. AT: "I will give the Egyptians over to the control of a harsh master" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will give the Egyptians into the hand of a harsh master

contextId.information: The word "Egypt" represents the people of Egypt. Going astray represents doing what is wrong. AT: "made the people of Egypt go astray" or "made the people of Egypt do what is wrong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: made Egypt go astray

contextId.information: Here "hand" refers to God's power, and raising the hand against them represents punishing them. AT: "because Yahweh of hosts has raised his powerful hand to punish them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: because of the upraised hand of Yahweh of hosts that he raises over them

contextId.information: "land of Judah" and "Egypt" refer to the people in those places. The Egyptians will stagger because they are afraid. AT: "The people of Judah will cause the Egyptians to stagger" or "The people of Judah will cause the Egyptians to be terribly afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The land of Judah will become a cause of staggering to Egypt

contextId.information: This refers to the people of those cities. AT: "the people in five Egyptian cities will speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: there will be five cities in the land of Egypt that speak

contextId.information: Here "Egypt" refers to the people of Egypt. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh will make the people of Egypt know him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will become known to Egypt

contextId.information: Here, "Egypt" refers to the people of Egypt. AT: "Yahweh will afflict the people of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will afflict Egypt

contextId.information: The names of the three nations represent the people of those nations. AT: "the Israelites will be the third with the Egyptians and Assyrians" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Israel will be the third with Egypt and Assyria

contextId.information: The names of the three nations refer to the people of those nations. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I have blessed you, people of Egypt, because you are my people; and I have blessed you, people of Assyria, because I created you; and I have blessed you, people of Israel, because I securely possess you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Blessed be Egypt, my people; Assyria, the work of my hands; and Israel, my inheritance

contextId.information: Ashdod refers to the army of Ashdod. AT: "he fought against the army of Ashdod and defeated it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he fought against Ashdod and took it

contextId.information: The place names refer to their people. AT: "concerning the people of Egypt and the people of Ethiopia" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: concerning Egypt and concerning Ethiopia

contextId.information: Hope and glory refer to their trust in the military power of these countries. AT: "because they had trusted in the power of the armies of Ethiopia and Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: because of Ethiopia their hope and of Egypt their glory

contextId.information: This refers to the people who live in Babylon as being a desert, even though God has not made it into a desert yet. This event will certainly happen. AT: "about the people who live in a land that soon will be a desert" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pastforfuture]])
contextId.quote: about the desert by the sea

contextId.information: Here "her" represents all the people who are suffering because of the Babylonians. Yahweh will cause them to stop groaning when he sends the armies of Elam and Media to destroy the Babylonians. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will stop all her groaning

contextId.information: Here "table" represents the food that people will eat at the feast. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: prepare the table

contextId.information: Arabia refers to the population of Arabia. AT: "about the people of Arabia" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: about Arabia

contextId.information: Here "Valley" refers to those who live in the valley, that is, Jerusalem. AT: "about those who live in the Valley of Vision" or "about those who live in Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: about the Valley of Vision

contextId.information: Here "day" refers to a longer period of time. AT: "For there will be a time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: For there is a day

contextId.information: The quiver is a bag to carry arrows and represents the archer's weapons. AT: "The soldiers of Elam take their bows and arrows" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Elam takes up the quiver

contextId.information: Here "house" represents those in the king's palace. AT: "who is in charge of all those who work in the palace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: who is over the house

contextId.information: Here "house" represents family. AT: "his father's family" or "his family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: his father's house

contextId.information: Here "day" represents a period of time in general. AT: "At that time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: On that day

contextId.information: Here "ships" represents the men on the ships. Isaiah speaks to the men on the ships of Tarshish as if they could hear him. AT: "Cry out in despair you men on the ships of Tarshish" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])
contextId.quote: Howl, you ships of Tarshish

contextId.information: Commerce is the activity of buying and selling goods. Here "nations" represents the people. AT: "you were where people from other nations came to buy and sell goods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: it became the commerce of the nations

contextId.information: Here "her" refers to the city of Tyre which represents the people who live there. AT: "their pride ... their glory ... their honored one" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: her pride ... her glory ... her honored ones

contextId.information: Here "ships" represents the men on the ships. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:23:01|23:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Howl, you ships of Tarshish

contextId.information: Here "day" represents a period of time in general. AT: "At that time" or "Then" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: In that day

contextId.information: Here "days" represents a longer period of time. The average time that a king lived was about 70 years. AT: "like the years of a king" or "which is about as long as a king lives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: like the days of a king

contextId.information: Here "Tyre" represents the people who live in Tyre. AT: "Yahweh will help the people of Tyre" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will help Tyre

contextId.information: The phrase "in the east" represents the people living east of Israel. Isaiah is commanding these people as if they were there with him. But, he is talking to the people in the future after God devastates the earth. AT: "Therefore everyone from distant lands in the east will glorify Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pastforfuture]])
contextId.quote: Therefore in the east glorify Yahweh

contextId.information: Here "day" means a period of time in general. AT: "at that time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: on that day

contextId.information: Here "name" represents Yahweh. AT: "praise you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: praise your name

contextId.information: Here "city" and "nations" represent the people who live there. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: a city of ruthless nations

contextId.information: The "hand" represents God's power. For Yahweh's hand to rest on "this mountain" means he will protect his people AT: "The power of Yahweh will be on this mountain" or "For on Mount Zion Yahweh will protect his people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: For on this mountain the hand of Yahweh will rest

contextId.information: Here "day" represents a period of time in general. AT: "At that time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: In that day

contextId.information: Here "mind" represents a person's thoughts. Also "you" refers to Yahweh. The phrase "The mind that is stayed on you" is an idiom that means "The person who continually thinks about you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: The mind that is stayed on you

contextId.information: Here "name" represents the person of God. AT: "but we praise you alone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: but we praise your name alone

contextId.information: Here "day" represents a period of time in general. AT: "At that time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: On that day

contextId.information: This represents the descendants of Jacob. AT: "sending the Israelites away" (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: sending Jacob and Israel away

contextId.information: Here "day" represents a period of time in general. AT: "at that time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: on that day

contextId.information: Here "word" represents a message. AT: "So Yahweh's message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: So the word of Yahweh

contextId.information: Isaiah now speaks to the leaders of Jerusalem. Here "word" represents a message. AT: "So listen to Yahweh's message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: So listen to the word of Yahweh

contextId.information: Here "words" represents a message. AT: "to my message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to my words

contextId.information: Here "Ariel" represents the people who live in the city of Ariel. AT: "How terrible it will be for the people of Ariel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Woe to Ariel

contextId.information: Here "she" refers to Ariel, which represents the people of Ariel. AT: "the people of Ariel will" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: she will

contextId.information: The word "I" refers to Yahweh. This represents Yahweh causing an enemy army to surround Jerusalem. AT: "I will command the army of your enemies to surround you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will encamp against you

contextId.information: Here "Mount Zion" represents the people who live there. AT: "Yes, this will be what happens to the armies from the nations who fight against the people who live on Mount Zion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Yes, so will be the great number of nations that fights against Mount Zion

contextId.information: Here "house" represents a family. AT: "the descendants of Jacob" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Jacob

contextId.information: Here "hands" represents Yahweh's power and action. AT: "When they see all the children I have given them and all that I have done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: But when he sees his children, the work of my hands

contextId.information: Here "spirit" represents a person's inner being. AT: "Those who are wrong in what they think" or "Those who are wrong in their attitude" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Those who err in spirit

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) the leaders of Judah are trusting in the Egyptian leaders who rule by oppressing and deceiving others or 2) the leaders of Judah have oppressed and deceived their own people in order to take their money and send it to the Egyptians leaders as payment for protection. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: trust in oppression and deceit and lean on it

contextId.information: The word "fire" here refers here to ashes. AT: "ashes from the fireplace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: fire from the hearth

contextId.information: Here this represents the soldiers of Assyria. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Assyria

contextId.information: This refers to the people who live there. AT: "the people of Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Jerusalem

contextId.information: "Sword" refers to military might. This can be stated in active form. AT: "God's sword, and not a man's sword, will destroy the Assyrian army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Assyria will fall by the sword; a sword not wielded by man will consume him

contextId.information: Isaiah is refers to himself by his voice to emphasize what he says. AT: "me speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: my voice

contextId.information: This speaks of Yahweh causing his people to be secure as if he were the stability himself. The phrase "your times" refers to their lives. AT: "He will make you secure all your lives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He will be the stability in your times

contextId.information: This speaks of Lebanon's trees withering and decaying as if Lebanon were a person is ashamed. AT: "Lebanon's trees wither and decay" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: is ashamed and withers away

contextId.information: Here "Yahweh" refers to Yahweh's orders. AT: "without Yahweh's command" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: without Yahweh

contextId.information: This means to fight against the people and cause destruction in the place where they live. The land referred to here is Jerusalem. AT: "against this  people and destroy their land ... Attack these people and destroy their land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: against this land and destroy it ... Attack this land and destroy it

contextId.information: This refers to the people who are left in Jerusalem. AT: "for the few of us that are still here" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: for the remnant that is still here

contextId.information: This can be stated in active form. The word "hand" refers to the king's military power. AT: "The king of Assyria and his army will not conquer you in Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Jerusalem will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria

contextId.information: This emphasizes that humans made these idols with their own hands and are therefore worthless. AT: "because they were false gods that men made out of wood and stone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: for they were not gods but the work of men's hands, just wood and stone

contextId.information: This refers to the people in the kingdoms. AT: "all the people in the kingdoms" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: all the kingdoms

contextId.information: This means that he sent a messenger to give a message to the king. AT: "sent someone to give a message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: sent a message

contextId.information: Here the king's "arrogance" refers to his arrogant speech. AT: "your arrogant speech" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: your arrogance

contextId.information: Here Judah's "house" refers to his descendants. AT: "the descendants of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Judah

contextId.information: This phrase "in your sight" refers to what Yahweh thinks. AT: "what pleases you" or "what you consider to be good" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: what was good in your sight

contextId.information: Here the king's "hand" refers to his power. AT: "the power of the king of Assyria" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the hand of the king of Assyria

contextId.information: Here "Sheol" and "death" refer to "dead people." AT: "For those in Sheol do not thank you; dead people do not praise you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: For Sheol does not thank you; death does not praise you

contextId.information: This refers to the people who live in Zion. AT: "you people of Zion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Zion

contextId.information: Here the word "arm" represents God's power. AT: "and he rules with great power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: and his strong arm rules for him

contextId.information: This refers to the people who live on the islands and in the lands bordering or beyond the Mediterranean Sea. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])
contextId.quote: you coastlands

contextId.information: These phrases represent the people who live in those places. AT: "People who live on the isles ... people who live at the ends of the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The isles ... the ends of the earth

contextId.information: This refers to the people who live on the islands and in the lands bordering or beyond the Mediterranean Sea. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:41:01|41:1]]. AT: "the people who live on the coastlands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the coastlands

contextId.information: Here the word "covenant" is a metonym for the one who establishes or mediates a covenant. AT: "I will ... make you be the mediator of a covenant with the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will ... set you as a covenant for the people

contextId.information: Here to be called by someone's name represents belonging to that person. This can be stated in active form. AT: "everyone whom I have called by my name" or "everyone who belongs to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: everyone who is called by my name

contextId.information: Here to "hand over" represents putting someone under the power of another. The noun "destruction" can be translated with a verbal phrase. AT: "I will cause the enemy to completely destroy Jacob" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: I will hand Jacob over to complete destruction

contextId.information: This refers to Jacob's descendants. AT: "descendants of Jacob, my servants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Jacob my servant

contextId.information: This refers to people descended from Jacob, Israel. AT: "you descendants of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: Jacob, and Israel

contextId.information: Here "house" refers to the descendants of Jacob. AT: "descendants of Jacob" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: house of Jacob

contextId.information: Here the word "name" refers to Yahweh's reputation. AT: "For the sake of my reputation I will delay my anger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: For the sake of my name I will defer my anger

contextId.information: This refers to the people who live on the coastlands. AT: "you who live on the coastlands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: you coastlands

contextId.information: Here the word "mouth" represents the words that he speaks. His words are compared to a sharp sword to emphasize that they will be effective. AT: "He has made my words as effective as a sharp sword" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: He has made my mouth like a sharp sword

contextId.information: Here the word "covenant" is a metonym for the one who establishes or mediates a covenant. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:42:05|42:6]]. AT: "make you be the mediator of a covenant with the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: give you as a covenant for the people

contextId.information: The word "tongue" represents what he says. Possible meanings are 1) Yahweh has enabled him to speak as one who has learned to speak skillfully. AT: "The Lord Yahweh has enabled me to be a skillful speaker" or 2) Yahweh has taught him what to say. AT: "The Lord Yahweh has enabled me to speak what he has taught me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The Lord Yahweh has given me a tongue as one of those who are taught

contextId.information: God speaks of their ancestor as if he were their father. AT: "Abraham, your forefather" or "Abraham, your ancestor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Abraham, your father

contextId.information: The city of Zion, which is also called Jerusalem, here represents the people of Zion. AT: "Yahweh will comfort the people of Zion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will comfort Zion

contextId.information: God's "salvation" here represents the result of his salvation, which is freedom. AT: "I will save you, you will be free forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: my salvation will continue forever

contextId.information: This refers to the people of Israel who are slaves of the Babylonians. This phrase describes how they work. AT: "The slave" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The one who is bent down

contextId.information: Yahweh's "hand" refers to his power. This speaks of Yahweh protecting Isaiah as if his hand were covering him to protect him. AT: "my power has kept you safe" or "I have protected you and kept you safe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have covered you in the shadow of my hand

contextId.information: Here "Jerusalem" represents the people who live there. Yahweh speaks to the people of Jerusalem as if they were there listening to him. AT: "Awake, awake, stand up, you people of Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])
contextId.quote: Awake, awake, stand up, Jerusalem

contextId.information: The word "cup" refers to what is in the cup. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:51:17|51:17]]. AT: "the cup of the wine that makes people stagger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the cup of staggering

contextId.information: Both of these refer to the people who live in Jerusalem. Isaiah is speaking to the people as if they were there listening to him. AT: "people of Zion ... people of Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])
contextId.quote: Zion ... Jerusalem

contextId.information: Here "you" refers to Jerusalem which represents the people who live there. It is understood that the uncircumcised and unclean people would enter the city to attack the people. The missing words can be added to make the meaning clear. AT: "enter your city to attack you" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
contextId.quote: enter you

contextId.information: Here "Jerusalem" represents the people who live there. AT: "People of Jerusalem, sit up and shake the dirt off of yourself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Shake yourself off from the dust; arise and sit, Jerusalem

contextId.information: Here "name" represents Yahweh's reputation. This can be stated in active form. AT: "those who watch the enemy take away my people are continually saying evil things about me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: my name is slandered continually all day long

contextId.information: Here "feet" represents a messenger who is walking. AT: "It is beautiful to see a messenger coming over the mountains to announce good news" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: How beautiful on the mountains are the feet of the messenger who brings good news

contextId.information: Here "arm" represents Yahweh's power. Yahweh showing all the people of the nations that he is holy and powerful is spoken of as if Yahweh were a warrior who removed his cloak, baring his arms for battle. AT: "showed his holiness and mighty power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: bared his holy arm

contextId.information: Here "nations" represents the people of the nations. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: many nations

contextId.information: Enemies not succeeding against Yahweh's people is spoken of as if their weapons would not succeed against Yahweh's people. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Enemies may form weapons to attack you but they will not defeat you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: No weapon that is formed against you will succeed

contextId.information: Here "fruit of the lips" refers to what a person says. AT: "and I cause them to praise and thank me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: and I create the fruit of the lips

contextId.information: "wicked fist." This shows that they fight viciously. "Fist" represents anger that is physically violent. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: fist of wickedness

contextId.information: Here "feet" refers to the traveling and work that the people did on all other days. God did not allow long travels or work on the day of rest. AT: "you stop traveling and doing what you want to do on the Sabbath, my holy day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: you turn back your feet from traveling on the Sabbath day, and from doing your own pleasure on my holy day

contextId.information: "Hand" represents power and ability. A "short" hand does not have power and ability. AT: "Yahweh is fully able" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh's hand is not so short

contextId.information: Here "hands" and "fingers" refers to their actions. This means they are guilty of doing violent and sinful things. "Your" is plural. AT: "For you have committed violent sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
contextId.quote: For your hands are stained with blood and your fingers with sin

contextId.information: "Feet" represents the ability to go and "run" represents doing it speedily. AT: "They are quick to do evil things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Their feet run to evil

contextId.information: Here "name" refers to Yahweh's reputation and character. AT: "fear Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: fear the name of Yahweh

contextId.information: This refers to giving someone something to say. AT: "the message I have given you to speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: my words which I have put in your mouth

contextId.information: The right hand and arm represent power and authority. AT: "by his power and authority" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: by his right hand and by the arm of his strength

contextId.information: Here "right hand" represents the power of Yahweh through Moses. This means it was God's power that enabled Moses to divide the water of the Reed Sea. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: who made his glorious power go with the right hand of Moses

contextId.information: "The sword" represents weapons of war that Yahweh will use to punish those who do not respond to Yahweh's call. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: destine you for the sword

contextId.information: "Hand" refers to the power and authority of Yahweh, not his physical body. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: My hand has made all these things

contextId.information: Here "sight" refers to Yahweh considering their behavior. AT: "They did what I consider to be evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: They did what was evil in my sight

contextId.information: The sound represents the real fighting that is going on in the temple as Yahweh is carrying out the punishment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: A sound of battle tumult

contextId.information: This expression represents all created living beings that shrink from the dead. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: all flesh
